title: CCTV catches police posing for The Beatles’ Abbey Road picture at 2.30am
text:
The police officers were spotted on the live EarthCam feed that’s fixed on the Abbey Road pedestrian crossing

Traffic on Abbey Road has been a nightmare for 50 years and we all know who is to blame.

Not a day goes past without legions of Beatles fans trying their utmost to recreate the famous album cover at the world’s best-known pedestrian crossing.

But it appears the Metropolitan Police have discovered the perfect time to beat the crowds.

Four officers were caught walking like John, Paul, Ringo and George at the ungodly hour of 2.30am on Saturday.

Another copper was seen in the middle of the road orchestrating the quartet with their camera in hand.

What they presumably hadn’t realised is that there is a 24-hour motion camera fixed on the crossing.

It had been a hard day’s night for this lot (Picture: EarthCam)

There’s a constant flow of tourists at the world famous crossing (Picture: EarthCam)

Most UK web-browsers would have been fast asleep, but a man in Montreal, Canada, happened to be watching the live EarthCam feed at 9.30pm local time.

The man, who wanted to stay anonymous, told Metro.co.uk that he often watches the Abbey Road stream as a fox comes out at the same time every night, and it helps him get to sleep.

He said he saw two or three police vans arrive and park out of view of the camera.

Minutes later he claims he watched as around five officers in hi-vis jackets assemble their feet into the iconic position.

It’s been 50 years since the Beatles released the Abbey Road album (Picture: PA)

He said: ‘Do their superiors know they’re out, wasting time pretending to be the Beatles, rather than looking after London?’

A Met Police spokesperson suggested the officers could have been off duty at the time.

They said: ‘We expect our officers to behave professionally at all times.

‘Since we can’t identify the officers from the image, it’s possible they may have been on a break or off duty at the time.’
